Exhibition: Divine Adornment: Community Stories of Belonging
Exhibition: Divine Adornment: Community Stories of Belonging All Day

IU Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, 416 N. Indiana Ave., Bloomington, IN 47408 - Room Number: William H. Mathers Gallery

Curated by fashion scholar Dr. Heather Akou, Associate Professor at the Eskenazi School of Art, Architecture + Design, "Divine Adornment: Community Stories of Belonging" uses pieces from the museum's collection to explore fashion from an Islamic perspective. The exhibit will focus on what fashion me...

Exhibition: "Whispers from the Divide" by Jawshing Arthur Liou
Exhibition: "Whispers from the Divide" by Jawshing Arthur Liou All Day

IU Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, 416 N. Indiana Ave., Bloomington, IN 47408 - Room Number: William H. Mathers Gallery

Eskenazi School Herman B Wells Professor Arthur Liou's video installation, "Whispers from the Divide", seeks to encapsulate the tangible and intangible barriers between the US-Mexico border. Through a series of pilgrimages to key locations along the border, Liou records a first-person journey and of...

Source: Indiana University Events

Individual Time Trials Little 500 Spring Series
Individual Time Trials Little 500 Spring Series All Day

None

In each heat, one rider will be placed at each of the four corners of the track. From a standing start, at the sound of the horn, each participant will make four complete laps. At the conclusion of the fourth lap, the timers will stop the clock. Riders will be sorted into groups based on their four-...

Ford-Crawford Hall

Buddhism and Mobility: Nomadic Monasteries of Mongolia, 16th-19th Century
Buddhism and Mobility: Nomadic Monasteries of Mongolia, 16th-19th Century

Wednesday April 02 - 12:00 PM to 01:00 PM

Hamilton Lugar School of Global and International Studies - Room Number: 4067

Beside stationary Buddhist monasteries, the Mongols also had itinerant monasteries with felt and wood temples that periodically moved in the steppes and mountains of Inner Asia. Most of them eventually settled down in the course of the 18th and 19th centuries, but up to the early 20th century, a few...

Source: Indiana University Events

Friday April 04 - 01:30 PM to 03:00 PM

Global and International Studies Building - Room Number: 1112

In 1980-81 at Wenxian, Henan province, China, over 13,000 stone tablets were excavated from the sacrificial pits in which they had been buried two-and-a-half thousand years before. On many of these tablets so-called "covenant texts" (méngshū 盟書), written using brush and ink, are still visible. Each ...

Category: Education

Exhibition: "Whispers from the Divide" by Jawshing Arthur Liou
Exhibition: "Whispers from the Divide" by Jawshing Arthur Liou All Day

IU Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, 416 N. Indiana Ave., Bloomington, IN 47408 - Room Number: William H. Mathers Gallery

Eskenazi School Herman B Wells Professor Arthur Liou's video installation, "Whispers from the Divide", seeks to encapsulate the tangible and intangible barriers between the US-Mexico border. 12:00 PM
Sustaining Hoosier Communities Information Session
Sustaining Hoosier Communities Information Session

Friday April 11 - 12:00 PM to 01:00 PM

Online via Zoom

Each year, SHC partners one rural community with Indiana University faculty, staff, and students for an intensive year to advance community-identified projects that improve Hoosier lives. Learn about the SHC program's benefits, eligibility, timeline, and how to apply by the October 2025 deadline at...

Source: Indiana University Events

The Pre-Mongol History of the Khalaj in Eastern Afghanistan
The Pre-Mongol History of the Khalaj in Eastern Afghanistan

Monday April 14 - 04:30 PM to 05:30 PM

Hamilton Lugar School of Global and International Studies - Room Number: 3067

The Khalaj are a people considered to be a branch of Turkish tribes. They live in West Asia, and, if we believe Vladimir Minorsky's hypothesis, some of them have assimilated amongst the Afghans and live there as the Ghilzay. It was also Minorsky who published surviving Turkish dialects of the Khalaj...

Bio O'Reilly is an environmental anthropologist who studies how scientists and policymakers participate in environmental management, both in regards to the Antarctic environment and global climate change. Through participant observation and ethnographic interviews, she examines how people and ideas...

REEI Colloquium Series: PhD Student Stanislav Menzelevskyi on"Chernobyl Cinema: Technology, Ecology, and Film in (Soviet) Ukrainian Culture"
REEI Colloquium Series: PhD Student Stanislav Menzelevskyi on"Chernobyl Cinema: Technology, Ecology, and Film in (Soviet) Ukrainian Culture"

Friday April 25 - 02:00 PM to 03:00 PM

Global and International Studies Building - Room Number: 3067

This talk explores Chornobyl's cinematic legacy from 1972 to 1996, highlighting shifts from Soviet utopian portrayals to post-disaster depictions of trauma, protest, and transnational collaboration. By analyzing underexamined pre- and post-Chornobyl films, it reveals how cinema shaped and reflected ...

Current Events at the Emeriti House, is a nonpartisan, moderated discussion of the facts and events that define the news and great issues of the day. TBD, will serve as general moderator during this intellectual discussion.  Emeriti House Programs are open to all emeriti faculty at IUB.
